claim.statement: Social distancing measures decreased the mobility by an additional 23% (95%CI: 20%, 27%).
claim.statement_location: Results paragraph in the main text: "Social distancing measures decreased the mobility by an additional 23% (95%CI: 20%, 27%)." (paper body)

data.source: Citymapper Mobility Index (CMI) based on planned trips on the Citymapper application; dates of governmental social distancing measures collected from official government and media websites.
data.sample_size: 1,025 observations across 41 cities (25 observations per city)
data.unit_of_analysis: City-day (daily Citymapper Mobility Index observations per city)
data.access_details: Citymapper Mobility Index reference provided (https://citymapper.com/cmi). Governmental measures were tabulated from official government and media websites (specific links not listed).
data.notes: Citymapper app covers public transit, biking, walking and ridesharing planned trips and does not include personal automobile navigation; CMI reflects users of the Citymapper app (not necessarily representative of all residents); dataset has a nested structure (observations clustered within cities) as reflected by use of multilevel modelling; social distancing classification: cities classified as having instituted measures if non-essential businesses were closed and further classified as moderate or intense.

method.description: The authors downloaded Citymapper Mobility Index data for 41 cities for March 2–26, 2020 and tabulated the timing and intensity of governmental social distancing measures from official government and media websites. Cities were classified as having instituted social distancing if non-essential businesses were closed, with further classification into moderate or intense. They analysed the effect of time and social distancing measures on mobility using a multilevel mixed-effects linear regression model.
steps: Download Citymapper Mobility Index (CMI) data for 41 cities for March 2–26, 2020.
Tabulate dates and details of governmental social distancing measures for the same period from official government and media websites.
Classify each city as having instituted social distancing measures if non-essential businesses were closed; further classify measures as moderate or intense based on intensity of closure.
Assemble dataset linking daily CMI observations with social distancing status and time (date).
Estimate the effect of time and social distancing measures using a multilevel mixed-effects linear regression model (accounting for clustering by city).
Report estimated change in mobility per day and the additional change associated with social distancing measures, with 95% confidence intervals.
Summarize median mobility values and interquartile ranges across cities at baseline and at end of study period; produce figure(s) showing trends.
method.models: Multilevel mixed-effects linear regression model (authors state use of a multilevel mixed-effects linear regression to estimate effects of time and social distancing measures).
method.outcome_variable: Citymapper Mobility Index (CMI) — mobility expressed relative to baseline (%)
method.independent_variables: Time (day/date), implementation of social distancing measures (binary indicator), intensity of measures (moderate vs intense) as classified

results.summary: Across 41 cities (1,025 observations), median mobility (CMI) decreased from 100% (IQR: 94%, 107%) on March 2, 2020 to 10% (IQR: 7%, 17%) on March 26, 2020. Mobility decreased on average by 3.4% per day between March 2 and March 26. Introduction of governmental social distancing measures was associated with an additional 23% reduction in mobility. There was no difference in mobility reduction between moderate and intense measures. Authors note limited generalizability to populations not using public transit.

metadata.original_paper_title: COVID-19 related social distancing measures and reduction in city mobility
metadata.original_paper_data: Citymapper Mobility Index (https://citymapper.com/cmi) (dataset referenced in paper)
